presentation
Class CubicParamCurve2D

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.geom.CubicCurve2D
      java.awt.geom.CubicCurve2D.Float
          presentation.CubicParamCurve2D
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.Shape, java.lang.Cloneable
public class CubicParamCurve2D
extends java.awt.geom.CubicCurve2D.Float

A cubic parametric curve segment defined by float coordinates and having extended capabilities: parameter-specified subdivision and computation of bounds on curve length.

Author:
Lenko Grigorov, Helen Bretzke

Method Detail

subdivide

public void subdivide(CubicParamCurve2D part1,
                      CubicParamCurve2D part2,
                      float t)
Subdivides this cubic curve and stores the resulting two subdivided curves into the left and right curve parameters. Either or both of the left and right objects may be the same as this object or null.

The splitting works as follows:
Let M be the matrix: 

    1  0  0  0
   -3  3  0  0
    3 -6  3  0
   -1  3 -3  1
and M^-1 would be 
   1   0   0   0
   1  1/3  0   0
   1  2/3 1/3  0
   1   1   1   1
Then a Bezier curve can be written as: 
   (1  t  tˆ2  tˆ3) M ([x1,y1]
                       [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
                       [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
                       [x2,y2])
for t from 0 to 1. Thus, if we want to split the curve at t=T, we get: 
   (1  Tt  (Tt)ˆ2  (Tt)ˆ3) M ([x1,y1]
                              [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
                              [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
                              [x2,y2])
or 
   (1  t  tˆ2  tˆ3) (1   0   0   0    M ([x1,y1]
                     0   T   0   0       [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
                     0   0   Tˆ2 0       [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
                     0   0   0   Tˆ3)    [x2,y2])
or 
   (1  t  tˆ2  tˆ3) M S1 ([x1,y1]
                          [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
                          [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
                          [x2,y2])
where S1 equals: 
   Mˆ-1  (1   0   0   0    M
          0   T   0   0
          0   0   Tˆ2 0
          0   0   0   Tˆ3)
or 
      1           0          0        0
     1-T          T          0        0
   (1-T)ˆ2     2T-2Tˆ2      Tˆ2       0
   (1-T)ˆ3  3T-6Tˆ2+3Tˆ3  3Tˆ2-3Tˆ3  Tˆ3
Thus, if we multiply S1 by the vector: 
   ([x1,y1]
    [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
    [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
    [x2,y2])
we will obtain the four points for the first part of the split curve.

Similarly, for the second part of the curve we have: 

   (1  T+(1-T)t  (T+(1-T)t)ˆ2  (T+(1-T)t)ˆ3) M ([x1,y1]
                                                [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
                                                [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
                                                [x2,y2])
or 
   (1  t  tˆ2  tˆ3) (1   T     Tˆ2       Tˆ3     M ([x1,y1]
                     0  1-T  2T(1-T)  3Tˆ2(1-T)     [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
                     0   0   (1-T)ˆ2  3T(1-T)ˆ2     [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
                     0   0      0      (1-T)ˆ3 )    [x2,y2])
or 
   (1  t  tˆ2  tˆ3) M S2 ([x1,y1]
                          [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
                          [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
                          [x2,y2])
where S2 equals: 
   Mˆ-1  (1   T     Tˆ2       Tˆ3      M
          0  1-T  2T(1-T)  3Tˆ2(1-T)
          0   0   (1-T)ˆ2  3T(1-T)ˆ2
          0   0      0      (1-T)ˆ3 )
or 
   (1-T)ˆ3  3T-6Tˆ2+3Tˆ3  3Tˆ2-3Tˆ3  Tˆ3
      0       (1-T)ˆ2      2T-2Tˆ2   Tˆ2
      0          0           1-T      T
      0          0            0       1
Thus, if we multiply S2 by the vector: 
   ([x1,y1]
    [ctrlx1,ctrly1]
    [ctrlx2,ctrly2]
    [x2,y2])
we will obtain the four points for the second part of the split curve.

Parameters:
part1 - the cubic curve object for storing for the left or first half of the subdivided curve
part2 - the cubic curve object for storing for the right or second half of the subdivided curve
t - the cubic curve parameter where the splitting has to occur (0 to 1)
